Author: Max Teodorescu
Article: Linear thinking yields linear results, but that does not necessarily ensure success. True innovation demands nonlinear thinking, which more often than not emerges from goal-oriented play and experimentation. Conductive ink, while not a toy, can help electronics developers in such play. For the design engineer, nowhere does play â aka brainstorming â function as much as a driver of innovation as in the prototype stage. The classic etched PCB has its place in the iterative process that is prototyping, but so too does the flexibility of conductive ink. Conductive ink  Spurred by the growth of low-cost, additive 3D- printing, conductive inks have regained attention in recent years despite having existed for quite some time. A 10-year forecast conducted by IDTechEx suggests that the conductive ink market will reach $400 million over the next decade. According to the report, âPrinted large-area piezoresistive, capacitive and biosensors are set to become one of the largest constituents of the greater printed electronics industry.â Brainstorming: the art of problem-solving Thereâs an implicit understanding that designs evolve over time as testing reveals more insight into what actually works. Therefore, design changes are inevitable, but creating new PCBs for each change takes time and effort. The use of conductive inks, like 3D printing, is an additive process that does not require harsh chemicals or highly specialized equipment to rapidly prototype multiple iterations early on, saving both development time and cost. Conductive inks thus encourage designers to brainstorm freely and explore new ideas without the time and hassle of etching or milling Â in order to define a conductive trace every time you implement a PCB change. As a result, conductive ink fits into both the traditional linear design process and into one thatâs highly agile.  Benefits The most obvious advantage offered by conductive inks is their ability to create flexible circuit paths on a wide variety of shapes and surfaces beyond the traditional glass fiber-reinforced epoxy resin. Inks are available at multiple cost points depending on their resistance and composition. For example, Methode offers ink-jet-printable silver conductive ink that claims 200 milliohms per square resistance, whereas London-based firm Bare Conductive offers a more affordable but higher resistance line of ink with 55 ohms per square resistance at $23.50 per 50-ML jar. Despite differences in underlying properties, most conductive inks are compatible with electrifying nontraditional materials, such as paper, plastic, wood, and plaster, expanding the range of possible solutions into unconventional territory. By freeing circuit prototypes from the confines of virtual space or the hassle of the etching, designers can now reintroduce tactile feedback into the brainstorming process. Limitations As with all tools, conductive inks have uses and limitations. There are two primary drawbacks. The first is their inherently high resistance compared to that of copper circuit board traces; ink has considerably more resistance for any given trace size than copper. For instance, the Bare Conductive ink has a resistance of 55 ohms per square whereas an equivalent copper trace has an approximate resistance of about 0.3 milliohms per square. This isnât necessarily a bad thing: Itâs true that resistance impedes the amount of current a printed trace can reliably carry, but low-current circuits dependent on voltage for their signal suffer no adverse effects. In fact, specific circuits actually require high inline resistance. Another circumstantial drawback worth considering is that if you perform your prototyping with a non-scalable technology unfit for volume manufacturing, youâd have to re-create the prototype with an etched PCB. But, again, thatâs not a bad thing; prototyping is an iterative process, not a single-sided task that starts and stops at very fine demarcations. Your first prototype should never be your last. Identify what assumptions must hold true for this to work Failing and re-creating the prototype helps ensure that youâve identified all possible constraints early, rather than discovering an incompatibility after the product has entered into production. Revising a product already in production costs significantly more capital than hedging early in the design process. Associational thinking In their book âThe Innovatorâs DNA: Mastering the Five Skills of Disruptive Innovators,â Jeffrey Dryey, Hal Gregersen, and Clayton Christensen observe that innovators think differently from ordinary people. âTheir minds excel at linking together ideas that arenât obviously related to producing original ideasâ using a skill called associational thinking. Associational thinking arises from learning and experimenting. Conductive inkâs fluidity â both literally and figuratively â adds an unconventional process to circuit building that may open up a host of possibilities in how to incorporate electrical circuit into system design. It may not completely replace copper, but it has its purposes. How far do you think we are from fabricating PCBs solely through additive processes such as conductive ink?
